data.title: [Merge Conflicts] Incorrect background decoration of splitter with empty "current" or "incoming" changes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10, OSX Sierra 

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open a text file and paste any of the following: 

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
Hello
=======
>>>>>>> merge1
```

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
=======
Hello
>>>>>>> merge1
```

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
=======
>>>>>>> merge1
```

**Expected:**
Splitter line (`=======`) should be colored the same as the editor background.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1278995/26985570-e3dfdcea-4cf8-11e7-854d-368c2d335919.png)


**Actual:**
 - Case 1: Splitter has incoming changes background decoration 
 - Case 2: Splitter has current changes background decoration
 - Case 3: Splitter has both current and incoming background decoration 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1278995/26985555-d1790932-4cf8-11e7-9471-78ffa54b5286.png)

**Commentary:**
This is just a visual issue, does not impact behavior. 

I suspect that [MergeConflictParser.scanItemToMergeConflictDescriptor()](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/6daf4d3602e18e608368f64b78152803b8fcccc2/extensions/merge-conflict/src/mergeConflictParser.ts#L99) needs to special case empty `content` for `current` and `incoming`. My guess would be a zero length range is constructed on the line just after the start range for `content` but as we have `isWholeLine: true` on the decorations, the editor will color the line regardless. We should either a) Allow `IDocumentMergeConflictDescriptor.[block].content` to be empty or b) not inject the decoration if the `Range` has 0 length.

data.title: environment variable substitution not working in tasks.json
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Update to 1.13.0
2. Quit VSCode
3. Open VSCode
4. Run a task where the command relies on env var substitution like ```"command": "${env.GOPATH}/bin/gnatsd",```

Results:
```
execvp(3) failed.: No such file or directory
The terminal process terminated with exit code: 1

Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.
```

Specifying a complete path to the executable works, but any path that relies on ```${env.*}``` fails.

- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

#### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Setup a debug environment
2. Pause the execution of the program
3. Add an expression in the `watch` section of Debug

#### Expects:
- It would be great if a user could have Intellisense powered expression writing.
- I would not expect `tab` to be treated like and input enter.

#### Actual:
- The `variables` section shows all the current variables grouped by scope.
- There is not Intellisense powering the expressions in `watch`section

data.title: [Merge extension] Support GNU patch --merge results
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Darwin 16.5.0

GNU patch's `--merge` is useful when you need to apply external patch but want to see conflicts inline instead of separate `.rej` files.

It produces outputs like following:

```
<<<<<<<
first content
=======
second content
>>>>>>>
```

They're largely similar to Git's own format, except don't have additional information like commit message or filename.

As a workaround, if I just add a space in the end of both `<<<<<<<` and `>>>>>>>`, Better Merge can already recognize it, but it would be nice to have this built-in.

cc @pprice

data.title: A way to identify code differences between 2 project folders
data.body:
_I know that VS Code is a simple editor and not an IDE. This request doesn't have to do with IDE implementation._

Let's say you have a boilerplate folder and that you're currently working on new projects (obviously all residing in a folder of their own), all using this boilerplate code as a starting point. These projects obviously have different code in them, but they are all founded on the boilerplate code you already worked on.  Suddenly you have the need to add features to that boilerplate code that you wish to implement in future projects, as well as the ones you're currently working on. You'd have to go back to that boilerplate folder, code the changes, and then do the same thing in all of the projects you're currently working on:  a complete hell.

It would be a great asset to have the ability to compare code from 2 different folders (project folders) so that we can assert how they differ, and therefore easily change what we need to in a way that helps to minimize code breaks. Maybe this is not the proper solution to the problem I'm describing...but I think you get the idea of the need ;-) 

Thanks for your time! :-)

data.title: [suggestion] Support for JavaScript Environments: Adobe ExtendScript
data.body:
Per [my conversion with vscode on twitter](https://twitter.com/VisualStudio/status/857683370435895296), I'll like to drop a request for/start a conversation around language support for Adobe ExtendScript. 

The print industry (where I work) is incorporating more tech & automation, which often means scripting Adobe products like InDesign, Illustrator, & Photoshop. There is a dirth of support & tooling for Adobe's archaic version of javascript, ExtendScript, both from the community & Adobe itself. Right off the bat, their preferred `.jsx` extension gets confused with React/JSX.

Currently, the largest body of open source development in this space seems to be centered around this github org: https://github.com/ExtendScript/. Notable contributions from users like [Fabian Morón Zirfas](https://github.com/fabianmoronzirfas) & [bastienEichenberger](https://github.com/bastienEichenberger).

As someone just starting to dive in, I find Adobe's stock resources very difficult to consume. I've been hoping for a collection of official TypeScript typings for each environment so I could have intellisense autocompletion around the different environment globals and insight into the native object types. It's also very hard to go from writing esNEXT to the ExtendScript base of es3.

Does vscode have any language facilities for upgrading/downgrading a project/code window's referenced version of javascript? In other words, on a vscode window by window basis, can one switch from es2015 to es3? Or switch `/.jsx?$/` environments from browser (ECMAscript), to server (Node), to some other document type (Adobe ExtendScript, Google Docs scripting, etc.)?

In my opinion, Adobe needs to take the first steps towards enabling good DX and modern tooling. Perhaps issues like this & toolmakers like Microsoft can inspire some conversation or even break contact with Adobe?

## TL;DR;
- Adobe ExtendScript is ancient. It's based on es3 and has entirely different globals
- Can vscode do anything to make the ExtendScript authoring experience better?
  - Language environment switching for language version & env globals
  - TypeScript typings for intellisense
  - `.jsx` grammar (not React-style JSX)
- Shot in the dark: can Microsoft use their voice to push Adobe to improve their automation tooling?

data.title: Hot exit: set backupPath as configuration to windows
Open same folder in two different Visual Studio Sessions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.2|
|cordova-tools|vsmobile|1.2.7|;

Before the last update I used to be able to open two sessions of Visual Studio and point them at the same folder.  Now a "feature" has been added to just switch to the existing Visual Studio.  I understand that there are split windows that I can use but this is not nearly as efficient for me as the two open studio sessions to the same folder.  My work around is to open the root folder in one session and the source folder in the second.  I would suggest that the check for an existing Visual Studio session needs to be removed as this is reducing the functionality.
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open a folder with Visual Studio
2.  press cntl-shft-n for a new window.
3.  Open the same folder as the existing Visual Studio session.
4.  The result is that the first Visual Studio Session is brought into focus and the new session is still blank.

data.title: Hot exit: set backupPath as configuration to windows
Breakpoint in Typescript stops debugger in Javascript (iOS Emulator)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.5
- XCode Version: 8.3.3
- NativeScript Extension Version: 0.7.2
- NativeScript CLI Version: 3.0.3

I am writing a NativeScript app and running on XCode's iOS Emulator, using the NativeScript extension. When I debug, I can set a breakpoint in my TypeScript code, but when the debugger stops, it stops in the JS transpiled code and steps through that code. This happens on every app I try, including very small NativeScript "HelloWorld" samples.

On a clean Mac, I did a fresh install of VSCode, XCode, NativeScript and it debugged correctly in the .ts code. So there seems to be something strange about the installation on my Mac. I have completely uninstalled and reinstalled VSCode, XCode, and NativeScript on my Mac, but the problem still happens.

As suggested on other bug reports, I added "trace": "sm" to my launch config but I don't see any additional output in the debug console.

This has been happening on my Mac since I first started developing on this project, early this year, on older versions of VSCode and NativeScript. It persists even after upgrades and reinstalls.

Launch configuration:
```
        {
            "name": "Launch on iOS",
            "type": "nativescript",
            "request": "launch",
            "platform": "ios",
            "appRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "watch": true
        },
```

I can see inlined sourceMaps at the bottom of the .js files. (I believe the NativeScript build scripts are adding '--inlineSourceMaps' to the tsc command line.)

(I first reported this on the NativeScript extension github but they were unable to help.)
